Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EaSM2--Wildfires and Regional Climate Variability - Mechanisms, Modeling, and Prediction
Award.AbstractNarration:
Wildfire is a key component of the climate system and plays an important role in regulating regional climate variability. The overarching goal of this project is to elucidate the role of wildfire in decadal climate variation and prediction. On the basis of wildfire observations in the past decade, the regions that the variability of fire is large will be selected for targeted modeling analysis. The working hypotheses are that the observed fire variability is regulated by regional climate variation and that the climate feedbacks from fires increase regional climate variability. Consequently, the simulation of wildfires and their feedbacks is essential for predicting regional climate variability on a decadal scale. These hypotheses will be thoroughly tested and the mechanistic process will be carefully analyzed using an extensive suite of observations and selected ensembles of climate model simulations. In this project, the modeling capability of wildfires and their climate forcing will be developed by building a new Region-specific Fire Model with Ecosystem Feedbacks (RFMEF). Regional climate forcing by wildfires and fire feedbacks to regional climate variability will be quantified. Lastly fully interactive regional fire-climate variability feedbacks will be investigated to understand the projections of decadal regional climate variability.

Understanding the interannual and decadal-scale regional climate variability is critical for designing and testing (regional) adaptation and mitigation strategies. Many atmospheric, oceanic, and ecosystem factors contribute to regional climate variability and most of these factors are already captured in the earth system models. One such factor not yet well represented is wildfire. The two-way interactions between regional climate variability and wildfire not only are important in improving the decadal-scale climate model simulation and prediction but also are necessary when applying the climate model to examine adaptation strategies targeted at the vulnerability induced by enhanced climate variation (due in part to these interactions) and to investigate the effectiveness of mitigation strategies of forest management practices. The open-source RFMEF fire model that will be developed for the Community Earth System Model (CESM) system and the climate modeling data that will be generated in the project will enable policy experts to conduct more in-depth analysis of climate policies in regions strongly affected by wildfire and allow other scientists to conduct climate simulations and prediction that include the fire-ecosystem-climate interactions and that are more suitable for their research and assessment needs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wildfire is a key component of the climate system and plays an important role in regulating regional climate variability. In this project, we improved the modeling capability of wildfires and their climate forcing, quantified regional climate forcing by wildfires, investigated fully interactive regional fire-climate-ecosystem variability feedbacks, and examined how the feedback processes are affected by climate change. A total of 6 postdoctal researchers and 6 graduate students were trained in this project among 4 research institutes and a total of 37 journal papers were published and 5 more are in review. The major resarch activities of this project include:

  • We developed the Region-specific EcoSystem-feedback fire (RESFire) model with dynamic plume rise for the CESM. We developed a new brown carbon module in the CESM to account for photo-bleaching and efficient convective transport on the basis of field observations. Ensemble AMIP simulations were conducted in order to understand fire emission effects on radiative and cloud forcing and their impacts on regional climate systems. (Lead institute: Georgia Tech)
  • Using the RESFire simulations, we conducted two sets of decadal simulations for present (2000-2010) and future (2040-2050) scenarios. We conducted model simulations to examine how draught, wildfire, and ecosystems interact, leading to a positive feedback in the regional climate. (Lead institute: Georgia Tech)
  • We analyzed how various climate systems and ecological processes affect fire severity and frequency in major wildfire regions and the associated effects on air quality. Particular foci were placed in Africa, which is the largest forest fire region, and North America.  (Lead institute: Georgia Tech)
  • We conducted perpetual winter simulations using the NCAR Super-Parameterized CAM (SP-CAM) to investigate the effects of aerosols on the Northern Hemisphere winter circulation. (Lead institute: Georgia Tech)
  • We developed a DLEM-fire model by integrating satellite observations and applied the DLEM-Fire model to reconstruct global fire history for the 20th and early 21st centuries. We also developed a new fire behavior model to simulate fire behavior and its impact on ecosystem dynamics. (Lead institute: Auburn University)
  • We investigated the recovery of vegetation greenness in the early post-fire period in North America by integrating two national-level fire perimeter datasets and the MODIS products. We developed new algorithms to estimate fire legacy effect on the NDVI data by comparing burned pixels with their surrounding unburned pixels. (Lead institute: Auburn University)
  • By using a combination of MODIS-based fire occurrence and LANDSAT-based forest loss data, we investigated the spatiotemporal patterns of fire-induced forest mortality in boreal regions in Northern Hemisphere between 2005 and 2015. The results show higher forest mortality in North America than that in Eurasia, and that forest composition and topography are the key factors influencing the spatial variations of fire mortality across ecoregions. (Lead institute: Auburn University)   
  • By using historical observations and future predictions of climate forcing, we investigated the spatial velocities and trends in global atmospheric aridity from 1950 to 2099. The results show Africa experienced drastic drying during the past 60 years, underlying an increased risk for wildfires in savannas and tropical forests. (Lead institute: Auburn University)
  • We simulated the climate effects of land-surface property changes due to large wildfires in the continental United States. Nearly a hundred of large fires were selected from the Monitoring Trends in Burning Severity (MTBS) dataset. (Lead institute: USDA Southern Research Station)
  • We simulated the emission and transport of fire aerosols from Southern Africa and to investigate the impacts of wildfire aerosols on the stratocumulus. We investigated both the radiative effect and microphysical effect of fire aerosols from Southern Africa on stratocumulus over the southeast Atlantic and how fire aerosols affect the temporal and spatial variabilities of these clouds. (Lead institute: University of Wyoming and PNNL)
  • We investigated anthropogenic BC effects on East Asian winter monsoon (EAWM). BC transported from northern South Asia by wintertime westerly and southwesterly is deposited on snow in the Tibetan Plateau (TP), giving rise to a reduction of surface albedo and an increase of surface temperature via snow-albedo feedback. The TP warming increases meridional temperature gradient and lower-tropospheric baroclinicity over northern East Asia, leading to the jet stream acceleration around 45 N, and intensifying of EAWM northern mode.  (Lead institute: University of Wyoming)
  • We investigated short-term (10-day mean and daily) fire aerosol effects on cloud and radiation over Southern Mexico and the Central U.S. The aerosol-cloud interaction effects are found to be larger than direct radiative forcing. (Lead institute: PNNL)
